results.title: A Grand Day Out
results.brief_description: Wallace and Gromit have run out of cheese and this provides an excellent excuse for the animated duo to take their holiday on the moon, where, as everyone knows, there is ample cheese. The moon is inhabited by a mechanical caretaker, who is not too happy about the two visitors from earth that nibble on the moon.

constellations_other.name: Silent adventures (Hollow Knight - Education)
constellations_other.description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

results.title: A Grain of sand
results.creator_credit: David Keith Hardy, John Luck and UNICEF
results.brief_description: Firstly children’s needs are dramatised through a poem by William Blake and drawings by Ronald Searle. Then we follow a 10 year old Tunisian Arab boy to a health clinic, a school and a vocational training centre - three concrete ways to help meet children’s needs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Keith Hardy, John Luck and UNICEF

results.title: A Gourmet tour. - Volume 1.
results.creator_credit: Gian Manara and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: The last decade has seen the emergence of an exciting and unique cuisine in Australia, arising from the multi-cultural nature of our society and the abundance of fresh, natural ingredients. This program is a gourmet’s tour of some of the best restaurants in the forefront of this development. It profiles the style of these famous restaurants, their chefs and details how to prepare some of their favourite dishes. Divided into three sections: Dining in Sydney and Dining with wine. Restaurants include Cleopatra’s, The Cellar, Berowra Waters, Taylors, Bangkok, The Barn, Cotswold House and Craigmoor.

results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.
results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: A Good catch: a film about modern fishing nets and lines
results.brief_description: Shows a new British development in fishing equipment, the use of high density polyethylene as a material for fishing nets and lines. It shows conversion into filament, the weaving of the net and the use of this type of net and line. The fishing scenes were shot off Aslesund, Norway and north of the Arctic Circle in the Lofoten Islands.

results.title: A Good beginning
results.creator_credit: Norwood Studios and Modern Management Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the right way to induct and train employees on new jobs. Seen through the eyes of a young girl hired to learn a data processing card-punch operation. Compares correct techniques with wrong techniques. Reminds supervisors of the need to relieve tensions in the new employee before useful training can begin.

results.title: A Goal to win
results.brief_description: A must for every school and netball club. “A Goal to Win” is unique in its concept as a training video. Some of the exciting aspects covered are: Concentration, Individual Fitness, Team Cohesion, Self-Discipline, Team Tactics, Individual Skills, Motivation and Training Routines. The video traces players from beginners to elite players.

results.title: A Global market
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
The complex economic activities performed by humans takes on a new perspective when viewed from space with remote sensors. Important questions are posed. How does mining interfere with the lives of local inhabitants? Can the Earth really support its population? A global image illustrates how all the continents of the planet are linked by trade and shipping routes.

results.title: A Global family
results.brief_description: Suzanne reflects on the impacts of her HIV diagnosis and in particular coming to terms with the fact that her dream to have children would not be realised in the way that she first imagined.
